links.*: A Closed Letter to Andrea Charicoryides Surnamed Polygrapheus, Logothete of the Theme of Geodesia in the Empire, Bard of the Court of Camelot, Malleus Malitiarium, Inclinga Sum Sometimes Known as Charles Williams
A Fragment of an Epic: Before Jerusalem Richard Makes an End of Speech
Adventures in Unnatural History and Medieval Metres, being the Freaks of Fisiologus
Bilbo's Last Song (at the Grey Havens)
Chip the glasses and crack the plates!
Cold be hand and heart and bone,
Dark Are the Clouds about the North
Far over the misty mountains cold
Farewell We Call to Hearth and Hall!
From dark Dunharrow in the dim morning
Hey dol! merry dol! ring a dong dillo!
Hop along, my little friends, up the Withywindle!
I Sit beside the Fire and Think
In Western Lands beneath the Sun
Lemminkainen Goeth to the Fords of Oxen
Over Old Hills and Far Away
Over the land there lies a long shadow
Poems in The Lord of the Rings

Sir Gawain and the Green Knight
Song of the Ent and Entwife
Song of the Mounds of Mundburg
Tha Eadigan Saelidan: The Happy Mariners
The Battle of the Eastern Field

The Complaint of Mîm the Dwarf
The Homecoming of Beorhtnoth Beorhthelm's Son
The J.R.R. Tolkien Companion and Guide
The Last of the Old Gods
The Lay of Aotrou and Itroun
The Lay of the Children of Húrin
The Lay of the Fall of Gondolin
The Lion Is Loud and Proud
The Little House of Lost Play: Mar Vanwa Tyaliéva
The Man in the Moon Came Down Too Soon
The Man in the Moon Stayed Up Too Late
The Swallow, and the Traveller on the Plains
The wind was on the withered heath
The world was young, the mountains green,
Twenty years have flowed away down the long river
Under the mountain dark and tall
When winter first begins to bite
Where now the horse and the rider? Where is the horn that was blowing?
The Mermaid's Flute from 'The Lay of Earendel'
The Horns of the Host of Doriath
An Ode Inspired by Intimations of the Approach of Early Morning Tea
Ye laggard woodlands and ye slumbrous brakes
I stood upon an empty shore before the sun was born
A Rhyme Royal upon Easter Morning
Moonshine: Verses in a Medieval Measure
Lines Composed in a Village Inn on an Evening of Extraordinary Liquid Beauty
The Tale of Beewolf Son of Echgethew
Völsungakviða en nýja eða Sigurðarkviða en mesta
Guðrúnarkviða en nýja eða Dráp Niflunga
Hit was an olde mon fro Pimbilmere
When little Louis came to stay
Though all things fail & come to naught,
My heart is not in this land where I live:
'At last the time has come,' he said,

wikitext.*:
{{poem infobox | title=''Meremenna Symbel'' | image= | caption= | imageWidth= | imageHeight= | other names=''The Sirens'',
''Sirens'',
''The Sirens Feast'' | written=[[July]] of [[1910]] | revised=Possibly [[May]] of [[1914]] | published=''[[The Collected Poems of J.R.R. Tolkien]]'' | subject=[[Sirens]] }} '''''Meremenna Symbel''''',{{CP|5}}, pp. 17-8 also referred to as '''''The Sirens''''',{{CG|Po}}, "By Title", p. 855 (entry "''The Sirens''. Unpublished.") is a poem written by [[J.R.R. Tolkien]] in [[July]] of [[1910]].{{CG|C}}, p. 19 (entry "July 1910") ==Poem excerpt== :Clawed by the frothy fingers of the hungry deep ::That moaned in restless agony around :Stood darkly once, its cruel and unrelenting steep ::Towered high, an isle by no man living found. ==Background== Sometime in [[July]] of [[1910]], [[J.R.R. Tolkien]] wrote the poem '''''The Sirens Feast''''' on the same manuscript that he wrote ''[[Wood-sunshine]]''{{CP|4}}, p. 14 on. At some later date, Tolkien inscribed "July 1910" on the manuscript and wrote the title in the margins. A few years later, possibly in [[May]] of [[1914]], Tolkien revised the poem,{{CP|Introduction}}, p. xv giving it ''The Sirens'' as a shortened name, but also naming it ''Meremenna Symbel'' ("The Sirens Feast") in [[Old English]]. On the manuscript for the second version, Tolkien also wrote the date of its initial composition in addition to inscribing "(pract[ically] unaltered)" and "Before untitled" on it. In a list of poems marked "[[Attempts at Verse]]", Tolkien included the poem with the spelling '''''Meremenna symbel''''' ("The Sirens").{{CP|A3}}, p. 1377 (list "A") Sometime after [[14 July]] of [[1915]], Tolkien included the poem, labeled as '''''meremennena symbel''''' ("The Sirens Feast"), in another list of poems.{{CP|A3}}, p. 1379 (list "C") Near "the end of 1915 or the start of [[1916]]", Tolkien included ''The Sirens Feast'' under the name '''''Sirens''''' as part of a list of poems he compiled,{{CP|A3}}, p. 1381 (list "D") only to strike it through.{{CP|Introduction}}, p. xxiii In [[September]] of [[2024]], the poem was published for the first time as entry 5 in ''[[The Collected Poems of J.R.R. Tolkien]]'' along with the earliest version. In their commentary, [[Wayne G. Hammond]] and [[Christina Scull]] described the [[Wikipedia:Sirens|Sirens]] in the poem as deriving from [[Wikipedia:Greek mythology|Greek mythology]] and being "generally depicted as women combined with [[birds]]", unlike [[mermaids]]. In a note to line 13 in the first version of the poem, Hammond and Scull explain that "''Gan'' is an obsolete form of ''gone''".{{CP|5}}, p. 18 (note "A13:") In a note on their "Addenda and Corrigenda to ''The Collected Poems of J.R.R. Tolkien''", Hammond and Scull corrected their note to line 13 to "a dialectal English form of the verb ''go''".{{webcite |author= [[Christina Scull]] and [[Wayne G. Hammond]]|articleurl= https://www.hammondandscull.com/addenda/collected_poems_by_date.html|articlename= Addenda and Corrigenda to ''The Collected Poems of J.R.R. Tolkien'' (2024) Arranged by Date|dated= 24 December 2024|website= HS|accessed= 30 December 2025|archiveurl= |archivename= |archivedate=}}, "Prior to 24 December 2024" Their notion was disputed by "some readers", who "suggested that ''gan'' is to be related not to Old English ‘''go''’ but to OE ''ginnan'' ‘begin’, thus ‘''gan''’ = ‘began’, or else should be understood to mean ‘did’, as Middle English gan is sometimes translated". ==See also== *''[[The Merryman]]'' {{References}} {{Poems}} [[Category:Old English names]] [[Category:Poems by J.R.R. Tolkien]]
